content.text: Close the switch
· Adjust the position of the crocodile clip, so that the length \(l\) of the slide wire connected is \(20.0 \text{cm}\)
· Record in Table 1.1 the value of the p.d. \(V\) and the current \(I\) for the lamp
· Move the crocodile clip and record values of \(V\) and \(I\) for \(l = 40.0 \text{cm}, 60.0 \text{cm}, 80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(100.0 \text{cm}\)
· Open the switch
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the resistance \(R\) of the lamp at each value of \(l\)
Use the equation \(R = \frac{V}{I}\)
Plot a graph of \(R / \Omega\) (y-axis) against \(V / V\) (x-axis)
State what the shape of the graph tells you about how the resistance of the lamp changes with the temperature of the filament
Justify your statement using your results from the graph and your observation of the brightness of the lamp as the length of the slide wire changes
statement
justification
In this type of experiment, it is possible to change the current and potential difference for the lamp by using a variable resistor instead of a slide wire
On Fig. 1.2, complete the circuit diagram to show a variable resistor used for this purpose
In this experiment, you will investigate how the resistance of a filament lamp changes as the potential difference (p.d.) across it changes
The circuit has been set up for you
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Measure the distance \(v\) between the lens and the screen as indicated in Fig. 2.1
Calculate a value \(f_{1}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation \(f_{1} = \frac{uv}{(u + v)}\)
Briefly describe a technique to obtain an image on the screen that is as sharp as possible in this experiment
Arrange the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1 and switch on the lamp
Set the distance \(u\) between the illuminated triangle and the lens to \(25.0 \text{cm}\)
Place the screen near the lens
Move the screen until a sharp image of the triangle is seen on the screen
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{I}}\), the height of the image of the triangle on the screen
Measure \(h_{\mathrm{O}}\), the height of the illuminated triangle, as indicated in Fig. 2.1
Calculate a value \(M\) for the magnification, using the equation \(M = \frac{h_{\mathrm{I}}}{h_{\mathrm{O}}}\)
Calculate a second value \(f_{2}\) for the focal length of the lens, using the equation \(f_{2} = \frac{\nu}{(M + 1)}\)
Keep the screen and lens in the same place so that \(u\) and \(v\) are the same as in (a)
A student suggests that \(f_{1}\) and \(f_{2}\) should be equal
State whether your results support this suggestion. Justify your statement with reference to your results
statement
justification
State one precaution that could be taken to ensure that the measurements in the experiment can be taken as reliably as possible
Suggest which of Method 1 or Method 2 is likely to give the more accurate value for the focal length
Explain the reason for your choice
suggestion
explanation
In this experiment you will determine the focal length of a converging lens by two different methods
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1
Illuminated triangle

parts.label: (i)

content.text: Measure the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring without any load

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode
LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Describe two precautions that could be taken when measuring the length of the stationary spring, to ensure an accurate reading. You may draw a diagram
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.2
Hang a load \(L = 1.0 \text{N}\) on the spring as shown in Fig. 3.2
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the stretched length \(l\) of the spring
Repeat the process for \(L\) values of 2.0 N and 3.0 N
Calculate, and record in Table 3.1, the extension \(e\) of the spring for each load \(L\)
Use your values from **(a)** and **(b)** and the equation \(e = (l - l_0)\)
Remove load \(L\) from the spring. Suspend object \(\mathbf{X}\) from the spring. Measure the stretched length \(l_{\mathsf{X}}\) of the spring
Estimate the weight \(W_{\mathsf{X}}\) of object \(\mathbf{X}\)
Explain how you obtained your answer
A student suggests that \(e\) is directly proportional to \(L\)
State whether your results support this suggestion
Use values from your results in Table 3.1 to justify your statement
statement
justification
The student wishes to plot a graph of \(L\) against \(e\) to test if the two quantities are proportional
State how her graph line could show that \(e\) is directly proportional to \(L\)
In this experiment you will investigate the behaviour of a spring
A stand and spring have been set up for you as shown in Fig. 3.1
A student is investigating ways of slowing the rate of cooling of hot liquids in a container
The student knows that a lid will reduce the rate of cooling. He wants to find out if the thickness of the lid makes any difference to the rate of cooling
Plan an experiment which will enable him to compare the effects of lids of different thicknesses. You are **not** required to carry out the experiment
In your plan, you should:
• list the apparatus needed
• explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation, including the measurements to be taken
• state any key variables that would need to be kept the same
• draw a suitable table or tables, with column headings, to show how the readings would be displayed (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how you would use your readings to reach a conclusion
You may draw a diagram if it helps to explain your plan
